case_name: Zenith Lamps and Electricals Ltd. v. State Government

facts.text: Five appeals were filed on certificates granted by the Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These five appeals on certificates granted by the Madras High Court raise companymon questions on law and will be dealt with together.

facts.text: The appeals arise out of Writ Petition No. 1321 of 1964 and Appeal No. 150 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: We shall give brief facts in one of the appeals  No. 150 of 1967  arising out of Writ Petition No. 1321 of 1964 in order to understand the questions that fall to decided in the present appeals.

facts.text: Officers of the Commercial Tax Department raided the premises of Zenith Lamps and Electricals Ltd. on August 19, 1964, at about 5.00 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: On August 19, 1964, at about 5.00 p.m., the officers of the Commercial Tax Department  hereinafter referred to as the Department  raided the premises of Zenith Lamps and Electricals Ltd.

facts.text: A suit-case was seized and forcibly removed by the officers during the raid.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter referred to as the companypany . It is said that the premises were searched and a suit-case was seized and forcibly removed by the officers who made the raid,

facts.text: The suit-case was informed to contain no papers or documents of the company but personal effects of managing director Shri Ramkishan Shrikishan Jhaver.

anchor.surface_text: in spite of the fact that they were informed that the box did number companytain any papers or documents belonging to the companypany and its companytents companysisted merely of personal effects of one of the managing directors, namely, Shri Ramkishan Shrikishan Jhaver.

facts.text: The raid was based on information that Shri Goenka, a Director of the Company, had removed a box containing secret accounts relating to the company.

anchor.surface_text: The raid and search were made by the authorities companycerned on information that Shri Goenka, one of the Directors of the Company had removed a box companytaining secret accounts relating to it.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that officers had no authority under Section 41 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959 to search and seize.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention of the petitioner in support of his prayer that the articles seized should be returned to him was under three heads. It was first companytended that on a proper companystruction of Section 41 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, No. 1 of 1959

facts.text: Petitioner contended that Section 41(4) authorizing seizure and confiscation was beyond legislative competence under item 54 List II Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was companytended that if Section 41  4  authorized seizure and companyfiscation of goods, it was beyond the legislative companypetence of the State Legislature, for it companyld number be companyered by item 54 of list II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution relating to taxes on the sale or purchase of goods.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that provisions authorizing search and seizure violated Article 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was companytended that of various provisions in Section 41 were capable of being companystrued as authorizing search and seizure the provision companytained therein were unconstitutional in view of Article 19  1  f  and  g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Similar searches and seizures occurred in other petitions, attacked on same grounds.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to refer to the facts in the other petitions which have resulted in the other appeals before this companyrt because in those cases also there was search and seizure by the officers of the department and their action is being attacked on the same grounds.

facts.text: State contended Section 41 authorized search and seizure, within competence, and constitutional under Article 19(5) and (6).

anchor.surface_text: All the petitions were opposed on behalf of the State Government and its case was, firstly, that section 41 authorised search and seizure secondly, that the State legislature was companypetent to enact section 41 4  under item 54 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution and thirdly, that the provisions in question did number offend article 19 1  f  and  g  of the Constitution and were in any case protected by article 19 5  and  6 .

facts.text: Madras High Court held Section 41(2) provided only for inspection, not search.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that section 41 2  did number allow search being made thereunder, as it only provided for inspection, and the search was a different thing altogether from inspection.

facts.text: High Court held Section 41(4) beyond legislative competence as not ancillary to tax on sale/purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the power of seizure and companyfiscation of goods companytained in sub-section  4  companyld number be said ancillary and incidental to power to tax sale or purchase of goods and therefore this provision was beyond the legislative companypetence of the State legislature.

facts.text: High Court held sub-sections 2, 3, 4 of Section 41 unconstitutional as unreasonable restrictions under Article 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the High Court held that sub-section  2 ,  3  and  4  of section 41 were unconstitutional as they were unreasonable restrictions on the fundamental rights guaranteed under article 19 1  f  and  g  of the companystitution.

facts.text: In one petition, High Court found search warrant for residential house issued without Magistrate applying mind, as columns not struck out and gaps not filled.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the above, the High Court also found with respect to one of the petitions that the search warrant issued for the search of the residential house by the Magistrate disclosed that the magistrate had number applied his mind at all to the necessity of the search of the residential house, for companyumns in the printed search warrant which should have been struck out were number so struck out.

facts.text: High Court found Section 41(4) not strictly complied with before confiscation, no proper opportunity given.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further found that Section 41  4  was number companyplied with strictly before companyfiscation was ordered and numberproper opportunity was given to the dealer to show that the goods seized and companyfiscated were number accounted for in his accounts.

facts.text: High Court allowed all petitions and directed return of seized documents, things, goods, photographs, negatives, translations, notes.

anchor.surface_text: In the result therefore the High Court allowed all the petitions and directed that the documents, things and goods companyered by the petitions should be returned to the petitioners along with photographs, negatives, translations and numberes made by the Department from the accounts etc.

facts.text: State of Madras obtained certificates from High Court to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madras then applied for and obtained certificates from the High Court to appeal to this Court and that is how the matter has companye before us.

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Act, No. 1 of 1959 imposes tax at 2% on dealers with turnover not less than Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 is the main charging section which provides that every dealer whose total turnover for a year is number less than Rs. 10,000 shall pay a tax for each year at the rate of 2 per cent. of his taxable turnover.

facts.text: Tax mostly payable at point of first sale in the State.

anchor.surface_text: the point at which tax has to paid on single point taxable goods is indicated in the First Schedule to the Act and that will show that in a large majority of cases the tax has to be paid at the point of first sale, in the State,

facts.text: Government empowered officers not lower than Assistant Commercial Tax Officer, Revenue Inspector, Police Sub-Inspector under Section 41(2)-(4).

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that the Government has empowered all officers of the Department number lower in rank than the Assistant Commercial Tax Officer, of the Revenue Department number lower in rank than an Inspector and all officers of the Police Department number lower in rank than a Sub-Inspector, to act under section 41, sub-sections  2  to  4 .

facts.text: Supreme Court held power of search implicit in Section 41(2).

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore numberhesitation in companying to the companyclusion that the power of search is implicit in sub- section  2  with reference both to the accounts, etc., maintained by the dealer and the goods in the possession of the dealer.

facts.text: Supreme Court struck down clause (a) of second proviso to Section 41(4) as repugnant to scheme of Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that Clause  a  of the second proviso being repugnant to the entire scheme of the Act, in so far as it provides for recovery of tax even before the first sale in the State which is the point of time in a large majority of cases for recovery of tax, must fall, on the ground of repugnancy.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Section 41(2) and (3) impose reasonable restrictions protected by Article 19(5) and (6).

anchor.surface_text: We cannot therefore agree with the High Court that sub-ss.  2  and  3  of Section 41 of the Act are unreasonable restrictions on the right to hold property or carry on trade for reasons indicated. We are of opinion that they are reasonable restrictions which are protected by clauses  5  and  6  of Article 19 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court order allowing writ petitions due to defective search warrant and non-compliance.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the final order of the High Court allowing the writ petitions must stand, though we do number agree with the interpretation of the High Court with respect to sub-section  2  and the finding of the High Court that sub-sections  2  and  3  are unconstitutional

arguments.claim: Power of search implicit in Section 41(2) as inspection of premises, goods, accounts requires entry

anchor.surface_text: The main dispute centers round the interpretation of sub-section (2) of section 41... Reading therefore these two provisions together, it is clear that the empowered officer has the right to enter the offices etc., and to inspect them

arguments.claim: Proviso to Section 41(2) confirms searches and requires CrPC compliance; proviso substantive not otiose

anchor.surface_text: Generally speaking, it is true that the proviso is an exception to the main part of the section but it is recognised... The proviso therefore bears out the construction that we have put on the main part of sub-s. (2)

arguments.claim: Precedent: proviso can be substantive enactment (Rhondda, CIT v Nandlal, State of Rajasthan v Leela Jain)

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to Rhondda Urban District Council v. Taff Vale Railway Co... These three cases show that in exceptional circumstances a proviso may not be really a proviso in the accepted sense but may a substantive provision itself.

arguments.claim: Section 41(3) complementary to (2); seizure after search if evasion suspected

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to sub-section (3). That provides for the seizure of accounts, etc... Reading therefore sub-section (2), its proviso and sub-section (3) together we are of opinion that they provide for search and seizure without warrant

arguments.claim: Seizure/confiscation power in Section 41(4) ancillary/incidental to tax power but proviso repugnant to Act's scheme

anchor.surface_text: justifies the power to seize and confiscate goods on the ground that it is ancillary and incidental to the power to tax... Clause (a) of the second proviso being repugnant to the entire scheme of the Act... must fall, on the ground of repugnancy.

arguments.claim: Clause (a) second proviso to 41(4) not severable; entire sub-s.(4) falls

anchor.surface_text: It is next urged that in any case the second proviso is severable... We are however of opinion that clause (a) of the second proviso is not severable... sub-s (4) with the two provisos must fall on this narrow ground.

arguments.claim: CrPC provisions including S.165 apply mutatis mutandis to searches under 41(2)

anchor.surface_text: the proviso to sub-section (2) which lays down that all searches under this sub-section shall, so far as may be, be made in accordance with the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure... Section 165 should not apply mutatis mutandis

arguments.claim: Safeguards in CrPC S.165 and Ch.VII make searches under 41(2),(3) non-arbitrary and reasonable under Art.19(5),(6)

anchor.surface_text: These safeguards... clearly show that the power to search under sub-section (2) is not arbitrary... We cannot therefore agree with the High Court that sub-ss. (2) and (3) of Section 41 of the Act are unreasonable restrictions

arguments.claim: Searches necessary to prevent tax evasion (policy purpose)

anchor.surface_text: Naturally his inspection will be for purposes of the Act i.e., for the purposes of seeing that there is no evasion of tax.

arguments.claim: No search power in residential premises without warrant under 41(2)

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. (2) does not give any power of inspecting the residential accommodation of the dealer and therefore it cannot be read as giving the power of search of the residential house

arguments.claim: Officers empowered (Asst CTO, Inspector, SI Police) of sufficient status

anchor.surface_text: the Government has empowered all officers of the Department not lower in rank than the Assistant Commercial Tax Officer... to act under section 41, sub-sections (2) to (4).

arguments.claim: High Court order allowing writs stands due to defective warrant, non-compliance, invalid sub-s.(4)

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the final order of the High Court allowing the writ petitions must stand, though we do not agree with the interpretation of the High Court with respect to sub-section (2)

holdings.text: The power of search is implicit in sub-section (2) of Section 41 with reference both to the accounts, etc., maintained by the dealer and the goods in the possession of the dealer.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no hesitation in coming to the conclusion that the power of search is implicit in sub- section (2) with reference both to the accounts, etc., maintained by the dealer and the goods in the possession of the dealer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inspection of offices/shops/godowns etc. and accounts/goods therein necessarily implies entry and search; harmonious reading of sub-ss.(1),(2).

holdings.text: Sub-section (2) of Section 41 does not authorize search of purely residential accommodation without a search warrant.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. (2) does not give any power of inspecting the residential accommodation of the dealer and therefore it cannot be read as giving the power of search of the residential house

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power confined to business premises (offices/shops etc.); proviso requires warrant for residential.

holdings.text: The proviso to sub-section (2) of Section 41 confirms power of search and requires compliance with CrPC provisions.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso therefore bears out the construction that we have put on the main part of sub-s. (2)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso substantive enactment (citing precedents like Rhondda, CIT v Nandlal); refers to 'all searches under this sub-section'.

holdings.text: Sub-section (3) of Section 41 complements sub-section (2) by authorizing seizure of accounts etc. upon suspicion of tax evasion.

anchor.surface_text: Reading therefore sub-section (2), its proviso and sub-section (3) together we are of opinion that they provide for search and seizure without warrant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seizure follows search; requires recorded reasons.

holdings.text: Clause (a) of the second proviso to Section 41(4) is repugnant to the scheme of the Act and must fall.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that Clause (a) of the second proviso being repugnant to the entire scheme of the Act, in so far as it provides for recovery of tax even before the first sale in the State which is the point of time in a large majority of cases for recovery of tax, must fall, on the ground of repugnancy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act taxes mostly at first sale point; proviso mandates tax recovery pre-sale, inconsistent.

holdings.text: Clause (a) of the second proviso to Section 41(4) is not severable; entire sub-section (4) falls.

anchor.surface_text: We are however of opinion that clause (a) of the second proviso is not severable... sub-s (4) with the two provisos must fall on this narrow ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso added in 1961 integral to sub-s.(4); legislature intended them together.

holdings.text: Provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, including Section 165, apply mutatis mutandis to searches under Section 41(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that safeguards provided in Section 165 also apply to searches made under sub-sec. (2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to sub-s.(2) mandates CrPC compliance 'so far as may be'; S.165 adapts to tax officers.

holdings.text: Sub-sections (2) and (3) of Section 41 impose reasonable restrictions protected by Article 19(5) and (6).

anchor.surface_text: We cannot therefore agree with the High Court that sub-ss. (2) and (3) of Section 41 of the Act are unreasonable restrictions on the right to hold property or carry on trade for reasons indicated. We are of opinion that they are reasonable restrictions which are protected by clauses (5) and (6) of Article 19 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: CrPC safeguards (S.165, Ch.VII), recorded reasons, time-limits prevent arbitrariness; for tax evasion prevention.

holdings.text: The High Court's order allowing the writ petitions stands.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the final order of the High Court allowing the writ petitions must stand, though we do not agree with the interpretation of the High Court with respect to sub-section (2) and the finding of the High Court that sub-sections (2) and (3) are unconstitutional

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defective search warrant, non-compliance with S.41(4) (now invalid), CrPC safeguards not followed.

precedents.citation: Rhondda Urban District Council v. Taff Vale Railway Co. 1909 AC 253

anchor.surface_text: Rhondda Urban District Council v. Taff Vale Railway Co. 1909 AC 253, where S. 51 of the Act thereunder companysideration was f

precedents.case_name: Rhondda Urban District Council v. Taff Vale Railway Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: a proviso may be substantive itself and in substance a fresh enactment adding to the main provision
precedents.cited_holding: though S. 51 was framed as a proviso upon preceding Sections, but it is true that the latter half of it, though in form a proviso, is in substance a fresh enactment, adding to and number merely qualifying that which goes before

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Nandlal Bhandari Sons

anchor.surface_text: Again in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Nandlal Bhandari Sons, it was observed that through ordinarily a proviso restricts

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Nandlal Bhandari Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: a proviso can embody a substantive provision rather than merely restricting the main provision
precedents.cited_holding: through ordinarily a proviso restricts rather than enlarge the meaning of the provision to which it is appended, at times the legislature embodies a substantive provision in a proviso

precedents.citation: State Of Rajasthan v. Leela Jain

anchor.surface_text: Finally, in State Of Rajasthan v. Leela Jain, the question arose whether the proviso in the Act under companysideration

precedents.case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Leela Jain
precedents.cited_proposition: a proviso can be an independent substantive legislative provision rather than a mere exception
precedents.cited_holding: the proviso in that particular case was really number proviso in the accepted sense but an independent legislative provision by which to a remedy which was prohibited by the main part of the section, an alternative was provided

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed.
